children.name: to hit sb/sth with your foot
kick
children.definition: to hit sb/sth with your foot
examples: The boy behind me kept kicking my chair.
He was dragged kicking and screaming into a waiting police car.
I could feel the baby kicking inside me.
kick[C] A2 a kicking action or movement:
One karate kick can kill someone.
And what a tremendous kick that was - straight into the goal from 200 yards.
give sb/sth a kick[]to kick sb/sthonce:đá cho phát
He gave the bundle a gentle kick, but still it didn’t move.
give sth a good kickkick it hard
If the door won’t open, just give it a good hard kick.

children.name: kick something down/over/around etc
examples: Billy was kicking a ball around the yard.
The police kicked the door down.
Who kicked the ball over the fence?

children.name: kick somebody in the stomach/face/shin etc
examples: There was a scuffle and he kicked me in the stomach.

children.name: knee
children.definition: to hit someone using one of your knees:

children.name: đầu gối
examples: ▪ She struggled free and kneed her attacker in the groin.

children.name: boot
children.definition: to kick sb/sth hard, especially a ball:
examples: He booted the ball up to the other end of the playing field.
Suddenly this big heavy guy came up and booted me in the stomach.
They booted himinthe head.

children.name: hit
examples: ▪ Be careful with that stick! You nearly hit me with it.

children.name: bang
children.definition: /bash/bæŋ, bæʃ/  to hit someone or something hard, often making a noise and hurting someone or damaging something: tông , đập, va

children.name: bang your head/knee/elbow etc
examples: ▪ I banged my head getting into the car.

children.name: bang something into/against/on etc something
examples: ▪ Tom bashed his knee against the table.
▪ He slipped, banging his guitar against the door.

children.name: bang/bash into/against
examples: ▪ Kids raced around the playground, banging into each other, screaming, and letting off steam.

children.name: collide
children.definition: if two people or things collide, they accidentally hit each other when they are moving in different directions: va vào nhau, đụng nhau
examples: ▪ Barker and Mason collided while going for the ball.
▪ When the plates of land that form the earth collide or slide past each other, earthquakes result.

children.name: collide with
examples: ▪ I backed out of the door and promptly collided with someone. ‘I’m sorry,’ I said.

children.name: crash into
children.definition: to hit sb/sth extremely hard, especially while moving very fast: lao vào, va vào
examples: ▪ Tyler injured his shoulder when he crashed into Jesse Lyons during practice.

children.name: bump
children.definition: to accidentally and suddenly hit part of your body against something:
examples: bump into[verb phrase] if you bump into something or someone, you hit them with part of your body accidentally when you are walking or running somewhere: va vào ai
▪ Jim turned suddenly and bumped into me.

children.name: bump your head/elbow/knee etc
examples: ▪ Babies are always bumping their heads.

children.name: bump against
examples: ▪ His right leg bumped against the parking brake.

children.name: strike
children.definition: if something, especially a heavy object, strikes something or someone, it hits them hard once:
examples: ▪ A house nearby had been struck by a falling tree.
▪ The ball struck him in the face.

children.name: knock
children.definition: to hit someone or something with a short quick movement:
examples: ▪ She knocked me with her elbow as she passed.

children.name: knock against
examples: ▪ The heavy video camera knocked against his hip as he walked.

children.name: knock into
examples: ▪ She turned and ran, knocking into bystanders as she went.

children.name: knock something against/into something
examples: ▪ One of the movers knocked the sofa against a doorway.

children.name: crack
children.definition: to hit your head, knee, elbow etc hard and painfully against something:

children.name: crack something on/against something
examples: ▪ He slipped and cracked his head on the steps.
▪ Mary cracked her knee on the corner of her desk.

children.name: blow
children.definition: a hard hit with someone’s hand, a tool, or a weapon: cú đánh, đòn
examples: The blow proved fatal.
She died from aheavy blowto the head.
Martinreceived a blowon the nose.
He had been struck aglancing blow(= a blow that did not hit him directly )by the car.

children.name: blow to
examples: He gave her a violent blow to the head.

children.name: strike (sb) a blow
examples: The assailant struck several blows before he was restrained.
Officer Stacey was knocked over by a sharp blow to the head.
He struck a blow which threw her to the floor.
RegisterIn everyday English, people usually say that someonegets hitor that somethinghitsthem, rather than using the nounblow:
Hereceived a blow tothe head.➔Hegot hit onthe head.

children.name: impact
children.definition: when one object hits another: va chạm
examples: Just after the impact there was a flash as the rocket exploded.

children.name: on impact
examples: Both cars burst into flames on impact.

children.name: punch
children.definition: alsosluginformal   to hit someonehardwith your closed hand, especially in a fight or because you are angry: đấm, thụi
examples: ▪ The woman claimed that she had been punched and kicked by one of the policemen.
▪ The actor slugged a photographer who got too close.
throw a punch[] B2 to hit or try to hit someone very hard with a closed hand in a fight:
▪ Rogers threw a punch at Martin.
▪ Foreman, once the World Heavyweight Champion, says ‘I never throw a punch in anger.’

children.name: punch somebody on the nose/in the eye/in the chest etc
examples: ▪ Dean punched her in the ribs and pushed her against the wall.

children.name: hit
children.definition: to hit sb with your hand or with something that you are holding in your hand:

children.name: ▪ Dad! Peter keeps hitting me!hit with
examples: ▪ The victim had been hit with a baseball bat.

children.name: hit sb on the nose/in the stomach/over the head etc
examples: ▪ There was a fight, and someone had hit him over the head with a chair.

children.name: hit somebody hardwith a lot of force
examples: ▪ He hit him hard in the stomach.

children.name: hit somebody backto hit sb when they have hit you đánh trả
examples: ▪ Don’t hit him, he’ll only hit you back.

children.name: slap
children.definition: to hit someone, especially on their face, with the flat part of your open hand: tát
examples: ▪ I was so angry I wanted to slap him.
slap[countable noun] C2
▪ If you don’t behave yourself, you’ll get a slap!

children.name: slap somebody across the face
examples: ▪ She slapped him across the face and stormed out of the room.

children.name: slap somebody’s face
examples: ▪ Dora slapped his face and ran home.

children.name: strike
children.definition: to hit someone, especially on a particular part of their body:
examples: ▪ Her husband had never struck her before.

children.name: strike with
examples: ▪ Evidence shows that the victim had been struck several times with an iron bar.

children.name: strike somebody on the head/in the stomach etc
examples: ▪ The court heard that the defendant had struck Payne repeatedly in the face, causing serious bruising.

children.name: whack
children.definition: to hit sb hard, with your hand or with an object: đánh mạnh
examples: ▪ If he said anything like that to me, I’d whack him!

children.name: thump
children.definition: to hit someone very hard with your closed hand, especially on their body rather than on their face or head: thụi
examples: ▪ Mike thumped Stephanie’s back several times to stop her choking.

children.name: bash
children.definition: to hit someone hard, especially in a fight: đánh mạnh

children.name: bash somebody’s head/face/teeth etc in
examples: ▪ I told him I’d bash his head in if he ever touched her again.

children.name: clobber
children.definition: to hit sb very hard, either with your hand or with a hard object:
examples: ▪ The kids are bored, and have nothing to do but clobber each other.

children.name: to make sb/sth fall down by hitting them
knock out
children.definition: to hit sb so hard that they fall down and become unconscious: hạ gục
examples: ▪ Jackson hit Brian hard with his left fist and knocked him out.
▪ He is a good boxer, a powerful puncher who has knocked out 18 of his 20 opponents to date.

children.name: knock somebody out coldso that they become completely unconscious
examples: ▪ The blow to Sergeant Lewis’ head had knocked him out cold.

children.name: knock down
children.definition: /over to hit someone or something and make them fall onto the ground - use this about people or objects hitting someone or something: đánh ngã , húc ngã, đánh đổ
examples: ▪ Jo was almost knocked down by a kid on a bicycle.
▪ One boy crashed into him and knocked him over.
▪ There was a crash as the cat knocked over something in the kitchen.

children.name: get knocked down/over
examples: ▪ As the crowd rushed towards the gate, several people got knocked over.

children.name: run over
children.definition: to hit and injure apersonoranimalwhiledrivinga vehicle: tông , đâm
examples: ▪ How can you run over a child and not stop?

children.name: be run over by something
examples: ▪ The boy’s dog had been run over by a car.

children.name: get run over
examples: ▪ Make sure the lights on your bike are working. I don’t want you getting run over.

children.name: punch out
children.definition: US to hit someone with your closed hand, so hard that they become unconscious:
examples: ▪ I got so mad I just wanted to punch someone out.
▪ The coach threw him off the team after he punched out a teammate.

children.name: knock off U
children.definition: knock off  to hit sth so that it falls off a surface:
examples: ▪ Part of the puzzle had been knocked off onto the floor.

children.name: knock something off something
examples: ▪ Ellie accidentally knocked a cup of milk off the table.

children.name: to hit an object, door, table etc with sth
bang
children.definition: to hit a door, table etc very hard with your hand or with an object, in order to attract attention or because you are angry: đập ( bàn , cửa )
examples: ▪ Thomas banged his fist on the table.

children.name: bang on/at
examples: ▪ I banged at the door but nobody came.
▪ He complained loudly until Val finally banged on the table and shouted at him.

children.name: bang something shutđóng sầm cửa lại
examples: ▪ Sherman banged the door shut.

children.name: knock
children.definition: to hit adoororwindow, especially with your closed hand, in order to attract the attention of the people inside: gõ
examples: ▪ Would you mind knocking before you come in?
▪ I waited a moment, then knocked again.
knock on/at
▪ Lula knocked at the back door and he appeared, dressed in pyjamas.
▪ ‘Mattie?’ called Jerry, knocking on the door.
knock[C]
knock at/on
▪ I had just turned out the lights when I heard a knock at the door.
knocking[singular noun] the sound of someone knocking::tiếng gõ cửa
▪ We were woken by a frantic knocking at the door.

children.name: hammer
children.definition: to keep hitting something very loudly and quickly especially with your closed hand, because you are angry, impatient etc: đập , đấm mạnh

children.name: hammer on/at/against
examples: ▪ The children hammered at the door to be let in out of the rain.
▪ Her heart hammered against her ribs.

children.name: tap
children.definition: to hit something gently so that it makes a light noise, especially in order to get someone’s attention: ' vỗ đập nhẹ
examples: ▪ Daley read the notes, tapping a pencil on the desk.
tap on/at
▪ She tapped on the window to attract his attention.
tap[countable noun] B2
▪ I was startled by a light tap at the door.
tapverb-pp-HIT
[ I or T ] to hit something gently, and often repeatedly, especially making short sharp noises
The branches tappedagainstthe window.
I could hear him tapping his fingers on the desk.
I was tapping my feet (= hitting the floor gently with my feet) to the music.
Someone tapped meon the shoulder.
tapB2nounHIT
[ C ] a gentle knock or touch, or the noise made by knocking something gently
I gave her a tap on the shoulder and she turned round.
There was a tap on the window - Dad was outside!

children.name: hit
examples: ▪ You have to try to hit the ball over the net.
▪ The first time I tried archery, I couldn’t even hit the target.

children.name: rap
children.definition: to hit something loudly and very quickly several times in order to attract attention:
examples: ▪ The conductor rapped the music stand with his baton and the violins stopped playing.
rap[countable noun]
▪ There was a rap at the kitchen door.

children.name: rap on/at
examples: ▪ Seeing her son outside, Mrs Evans rapped on the window and called him back into the house.

children.name: strike
children.definition: to hit something hard, especially in a very controlled or skilful way:
examples: ▪ Morris struck his drum, and the band started to march down the street.
▪ In anger, he struck the wall with a stick.

children.name: bash
children.definition: alsogive something a bashBritish   informal to hit something hard with your hand or with a stick, hammer etc especially in a careless way:
examples: ▪ If the television stops working, just bash it a couple of times -- that usually helps.
▪ I put the box on the floor and gave it a good bash with my hammer, but it still wouldn’t open.

children.name: whack
children.definition: to hit something hard and noisily, especially using a flat object:
examples: ▪ Buckley whacked the ball into left field.
▪ The Georgia man whacked his fist on the bar.

children.name: beat up
children.definition: to hit someone hard and repeatedly all over their body, leaving them badly hurt and often unable to move: đập tơi bời
examples: ▪ He would come home drunk, get into a fight with Mom, and beat her up.
▪ Carl got beaten up outside a nightclub on Saturday night.

children.name: beat up on sb U
children.definition: beat up on  American torepeatedlyhit someoneweakerthan yourself, for example a younger child at school:

children.name: đánh tơi bời
examples: ▪ He was a bully, a mean kid who beat up on the other kids.

children.name: beat
children.definition: to hit sb hard and repeatedly with your hand or with sth such as a stick:
examples: ▪ It was clear that she had been badly beaten by her husband.

children.name: beat with
examples: ▪ Police officers had beaten the man with their batons.

children.name: beat sb black and bluebeat someone so hard that their body is covered in marks
examples: ▪ The child had been beaten black and blue.

children.name: beat the living daylights out of sbbeat sb very hard and violently
examples: ▪ Osborne wanted to beat the living daylights out of Flanagan.

children.name: batter
children.definition: to repeatedly hit someone in an uncontrolled and violent way:
examples: ▪ Teachers suspect that the child is being battered regularly by his parents.

children.name: batter with
examples: ▪ There were reports of soldiers battering prisoners with their rifles.

children.name: batter somebody to deathuntil they are dead
examples: ▪ The jury heard how Thompson had been maddened by what he saw and battered his wife to death.

children.name: knock sb about
children.definition: knock somebody aboutBritish /knocksomebodyaroundAmerican  to hit sb several times, especially in order to frighten them:
examples: ▪ My father used to knock my mother about when he was drunk.
▪ They had been threatened with a gun, pushed, shoved, and knocked around.

children.name: club
children.definition: to hit someone very hard, especially on the head with a thick heavy object:
examples: ▪ Football fans were clubbed by riot police trying to stop the violence.

children.name: club somebody to deathuntil they are dead
examples: ▪ Baby seals are clubbed to death for their fur.

children.name: to hit sb in a friendly way etc
slap sb on the back
children.definition: slap/clap somebody on the back  to hit someone on the back with the flat part of your hand, for example as a friendly greeting or in order to praise them:
examples: ▪ ‘How are you? I haven’t seen you for ages,’ she said, slapping Jim on the back.
▪ The coach said ‘Well done!’ and clapped each player on the back as they entered the changing room.

children.name: pat
children.definition: to gently hit someone, usually on their back, shoulder, or head, in order to praise them or show them that you like them: vỗ nhẹ
examples: ▪ Roz reached over and patted her hand.
▪ He got up, patted her on the shoulder, and gave her a quick kiss.

children.name: into
children.definition: prepositionTOUCHING FORCEFULLY
examples: used to show movement which involves something touching something else with
a lot of force but without moving inside it
_He's always walking into things when he hasn't got his glasses on.
